column2: Marxism is a political ideology that is derived from the ideas of Karl Marx. The three primary aspects of Marxism are the dialectical and materialist concept of history, the critique of capitalism and the Advocacy of proletarian revolution.

The Young Bengal movement was a movement by patriotic and passionate young Bengalis that strove to get get rid of British Rule. This group comprised primarily of of radical Bengali free thinkers emerging from Hindu College, Calcutta in the early 19th century. These individuals were also called Derozians after their teacher at the Hindu College, Henry Louis Vivian Derozio. This movement left a distinct mark in Calcutta society in the 1830s and 1840s.

Oxbridge is the collaboration or the blend between University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge in England. This word could be used as a noun referring to either or both universities or as an adjective describing them or their students.

Social History could be divided into two branches, the new social history and the old social history. The main difference between the two is that the former concentrates more on the politics and diplomacy of events where as the latter concentrated on the topics and people without a central theme. This transition from old social history to new social history took place in the 1960�??s. Moreover, since the 1990�??s social history is now beginning to focus on cultural history, that is the importance of language, beliefs and assumptions.
column3: and the focus on relations between social group

column2: Radicalism is the term that is used to describe the political ideology that involves  supporting or seeking political reforms that include extreme and dramatic changes to the social order. Radicalism could be applied toward the liberals, the right, the left or any other political ideology.

Communism is considered to be a branch of socialism. It is a social movement and a policy party, and is associated with nation-states such as the USSR, China and Vietnam. Communism envisions a utopia in which classes are abolished and property is controlled. In it�??s statements, it professes to provide an alternative to the problems of capitalism, imperialism and nationalism.

Gandhian Politics is the political methods and the political resources that Mahatma Gandhi used and tapped to free India from colonial rule. He worked with the existing political structures but managed to make his contribution unique. His politics are renowned worldwide. Some of the most famous of Ganhi�??s politics are, �??satyagraha�?? or the path of truth, �??ahimsa�?? or non-violence and self reliance.

The Moghuls were an Islamic imperial power that ruled a large portion of the Indian subcontinent. The rule began in 1526 with the descendants of the Timurid dynasty. Babur was the first ruler of the Mogul empire. The peak of Mughal rule in India was in 1700 when they controlled most of the Indian sub-continent extending from Bengal in the East to Baluchistan in the West, Kashmir in the North and Kaveri in the South. The rule of the Mugul empire came to an end in the 19th century due to Hindu uprisings and the power of the British Raj. The last Mughal king was Humayun.

The Indian National Congress (INC) is one of the most prominent political parties in India. This party was founded in 1885 by some of the leading political figures of the time. The INC played a major role in the Indian Independence Movement against British Rule. During the freedom movement the INC had 15 million members and over 70 million participants nation wide. Moreover, even after independence in 1947, it remained the main political party in Indian politics, lead by the Nehru-Gandhi family. It is currently the ruling party in the country.

The Cripps mission was an attempt by the British government to gain the cooperation and support of India for their efforts in World War 2. The leader of this mission was  Sir Stafford Cripps, a senior left-wing politician and government minister in the War Cabinet of Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

The Calcutta Riots also known as the �??Great Calcutta Killings�?? was the most deadly event in the history of the city. It was a prolonged massacre between 1946 and 1947. However, the most violent part of this was the four days of massive killing between August 16 and 19, 1946. Many thousands died due to this massacre and these riots.

Since its launch in 1976, History Workshop Journal has become one of the world's leading historical journals. Through incisive scholarship and imaginative presentation it brings past and present into dialogue, engaging readers inside and outside universities. HWJ publishes a wide variety of essays, reports and reviews, ranging from literary to economic subjects, local history to geopolitical analyses. Clarity of style, challenging argument and creative use of visual sources are especially valued.

The Annales school is a school of history that is based on the French-language scholarly journal �??Annales d'histoire ̩conomique et sociale�??. Its main focus is on the pre-modern world, that is the period before the French revolution. It deals mainly with social themes and an overall macro historical analysis of societies over a long period of time. Thus focuses on interdisciplinary approaches surrounding society. It has been the main source of influence in French history as well as European history.

The National archives is a UK government department. It is also an executive agency of the Secretary of State for Justice. This department and agency was created in 2003 in order to maintain a national archive for England, Wales and the central UK government. There are separate national archives for the different parts of the UK.

The Hungarian Revolution took place between 23 October until 10 November 1956 when a student lead demonstration marched through central Budapest to the Parliament Building. This revolt was a protest against the Soviet imposed policies of the People�??s Republic of Hungary. Many organized themselves into militias fighting the State Security Police and the Soviet troops. This revolt spread all across Hungary very quickly and garnered a lot of support.

Positivism is a philosophy of science that holds the only authentic knowledge is that which is based on sense experience and positive verification. This positivist approach was developed by Auguste Comte in the early 19th century. This approach has been expanded upon by other philosophers and sociologists in the later centuries.

Puranik Hinduism is the Hinduism that is depicted in the genre of important Hindu religious texts, Puranas. The Puranas are written in the form of stories that are related by one person to another. They stress on a particular deity and employ an abundance of religious and philosophical concepts. Puranic Hinduism is very common.

The Dutch East India Company was established in 1602. It was originally constituted as a chartered company, when the States-General of the Netherlands granted it a 21 year monopoly to carry out colonial activities in Asia. It was one of the first megacorporations  that had the power to issue stock and possessed several important government powers.

This is a branch of economics that analyzes social welfare measured in terms of economic activities of the individual. It uses microeconomic techniques to do so and also  determine the allocative efficiency and the income distribution within the society. Thus the individual units for these measurements of welfare economics are individuals.

Westernization is a process whereby societies adopt Western culture in several different fields of life. It has become a very pervasive process and is still spreading very quickly all over the world. Westernization could be thought of when influences and interests and people wish to change to a more Western society. It could also be thought of as a result of Western expansion and colonialism of native societies.

Modernization is basically the transition from the pre-modern or traditional society to a modern one. This is basically the process that nations that have achieved modernity go through. Many historian link this modernity with industrialization, urbanization and the spread of education.

Sublatern Studies is the field that is devoted to the study of history from below, especially realms of social life and culture that are obscured by colonial records. This term could be applied more broadly to other projects that seek to challenge dominant epistemes in the pursuit of more situated forms of knowledge.

The �??adda�?? is an intellectual gathering among members of the Bengali intelligentsia. It started off as a leisurely activity in locations such as coffee houses, and was most popular among the young middle class Bengali intelligentsia. The concept of the adda has its roots in the city of Calcutta especially during the early 20th century. In modern times the concept has become more fluid.

The Buddhir Mukti Andolan was the Freedom of Intellect Movement which was started by the Bengali speaking and writing Muslim intelligentsia in the 1920s and the 1930s. This was a rational humanist movement whereby the intellectuals who still defined themselves as Muslims critiqued Islam and called for a subordination of its tenets to the principles of socio-economic well being and individual freedom and creativity. �?�

The Common Wealth is considered to be a successor of the British Empire. It started to form when many of the colonies began to gain independence. The formal organization of the Common Wealth was developed from the Imperial Conferences where the independence of certain colonies was established.

column1: Oxford Center for South Asian Studies

column2: The British raj as the name suggests is the region under the rule. It refers to the period of British colonial rule over South Asia between 1858 and 1947. The British first established a stronghold over India when the rule of the British East India company, a commercial enterprise was transferred to the crown, the Queen of England. The region that the British rule covered consisted of British administered areas as well as Indian princely states.

This book is a powerful account on postcolonial cultures and how the power structures were involved in the cultural history and literature of colonial states. It illustrates the postcolonial discourse by the writers and intellectuals of former colonized nations and their own interpretation of their culture and identity.

Structuralism is an approach to analyze a specific field as a complex system of interrelated parts. Its basis is on the foundation that lies beneath the surface of meaning. It began with the study of linguistics but then began to be applied to several other fields. Thus it became an intellectual movement and not just a method.

Post Modernism literally means after modernism. It is usually associated with difference, separation, textuality and skepticism. It is a departure from all that is linked with the �??modern,�?? such as identity, unity, authority and certainty. Thus it is a rejection of the scientific approach that became prevalent during the Enlightenment.

Deconstruction is an approach, introduced by French philosopher Jacques Derrida. This approach emphasizes that any text has several meanings and interpretations. It maintains that the foundations that the text is based upon are unstable, complex and irreducible.

Orientalism is the term that is used in the West to describe many aspects of Eastern cultures. This  term was coined when artists, writers and designers from the West derived elements of their work from these Eastern cultures.

This term refers to a cultural movement and a period of social reform. It took place in the region of Bengal during the British Raj in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Bengal during this period was teeming with religious reformers, social reformers, scholars, intellectuals, scientists, literary geniuses, journalists, patriotic orators and freedom fighters. All of these individuals made unique intellectual and creative contributions to this movement. Thus this movement reflected a type of Renaissance.

Leftist Rule could be described as the rule or the political power of the Left. The Left in politics means those who support social change to create a more equal society. Their political ideology is based on socialism, anarchism and communism. West Bengal is one of the Indian states where the political power of the Left is still very prominent.

On December 6th, 1992, a mob of Hindu militants demolished the Babri Masjid or Mosque of Babur in the historic Indian town of Ayodhya and attacked other Muslim targets in the north. Hindu extremists believe that a Hindu temple should have been built in its place since it is the birthplace of an important Hindu god, Lord Rama. This event lead to the worst inter-community conflict since the partition in 1947.

The Gujrat Riots were the result of the burning of the Sabarmati Express train at Godhra city in the state of Gujarat. This took place on February 27, 2002 when the train was forcibly attacked by a large Muslim mob. This resulted in the death of many Hindu passengers who were returning from the holy city of Ayodhya and consequently severe massacres and riots that led to the death of many thousand Hindus and Muslims.
Definition
prosperous, well-educated people, typically Bengalis, regarded as members of a social class

The CPI(M) was formed at the Seventh Congress of the Communist Party of India held in Calcutta from October 31 to November 7, 1964. The CPI(M) was born in the struggle against revisionism and sectarianism in the communist movement at the international and national level, in order to defend the scientific and revolutionary tenets of Marxism-Leninism and its appropriate application in the concrete Indian conditions. The CPI(M) combines the heritage of the anti-imperialist struggle and the revolutionary legacy of the undivided Communist Party which was founded in 1920. Over the years, the Party has emerged as one of the foremost Left forces in the country.
a Hindu caste members of which were traditionally employed as scribes

One of the premiere colleges of India, located in Delhi.  It was founded in 1881.

chartered companies formed in the seventeenth century by various European states (England, the Netherlands, Denmark, Portugal, France etc). The companies held a monopoly in trade between their respective countries and Asia

Kashmir was ruled by independent sultans from 1320 to 1586, after which it was taken by the Mughals

the words and deeds of Muhammad, the Prophet of Islam
a system of medicine practiced in parts of South Asia thought to be derived via medieval Muslim physicians from Byzantine Greece
a Muslim empire that lasts from 1299 to 1923. Established in Anatolia first, it ruled much of southeastern Europe, western Asia and North Africa at the height of its power
the empire set up in western Europe following the coronation of Charlemagne as emperor in the year 800. Lasted till 1806
the people of a nation, state, or society considered collectively as an organized group of citizens
focusing on European culture or history to the exclusion of a wider view of the world; implicitly regarding European culture as pre-eminent
a physician using traditional remedies in India and Muslim countries
a popular style used in writing the Perso-Arabic script
the language or dialect spoken by the ordinary people of a country or region

a member of a strictly orthodox Sunni Muslim sect founded by Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab (1703�??92). It advocates a return to the early Islam of the Koran and Sunna, rejecting later innovations; the sect is still the predominant religious force in Saudi Arabia
a former empire consisting of Great Britain and its possessions, dominions, and dependencies
a Bhumihar Brahmin state that was under Mughal and then British tutelage before joining the Indian Union
Persianized form of the Khariboli dialect of Urdu
designation for various nomads who were subjects of the Mongol Empire
a region ruled by a khan (a Mongol or Turkic supreme tribal leader)
a body of Muslim scholars who are recognized as having specialist knowledge of Islamic sacred law and theology
a Shia school of thought that emphasizes the need for conformance to the opinion of authorities of Islamic law
ruled by the Nawabs of Awadh who became independent from Mughal rule in the eighteenth but soon thereafter came under British rule

name given, by themselves, to the untouchables of Hindu society
the part of Asia south of the Himalayas, today consisting of Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan and Sri Lanka
the official name given in India to the caste considered �??untouchable�?? in orthodox Hindu scriptures and practice, officially regarded as socially disadvantaged
people belonging to the lowest-caste Hindu group or people outside the caste system. The term arises from the belief among higher castes that touching such persons��amounts to ritual pollution
political positions and activism based on an aspect of identity (e.g. ethnicity , religion, sex, or sexual orientation) shared by a group which feels that its concerns are not adequately represented

political organization founded in 1906 to protect the rights of��Muslims��in British India. Its deadlock with the Indian National Congress over the form of government in independent India ultimately led to the partition of British India into India and Pakistan
a community that lives mainly in West Bengal, Bangladesh and Assam
a community outside the four-tier caste system and whose members were traditionally boatmen or cultivators
the ability of an individual to improve her economic status
a nonviolent movement in India led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi from 1920 to 1922 to resist British rule
a nonviolent movement in India led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi in 1930 to resist British rule

Hindu festival dedicated to the goddess Kali

riots in Noakhali, Bengal in the months following the Great Calcutta Killings of 1946
a Communist-led sharecropper movement in Bengal in 1946

the categorization of Hindu society by four castes, Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas and Shudras

philosophy and practice of nonviolent resistance espoused by Gandhi

An organized military force equipped for fighting on land.
A��monotheistic��religion[ based on the life and teachings of��Jesus as the son of God.
A person who adheres to�?��Christianity, an�?��Abrahamic,�?��monotheistic�?��religion�?��based on the life and teachings of�?��Jesus of Nazareth as the son of God.
A human subject or agent with legally prescribed rights and responsibilities. Citizenship status is granted by states and nations, it is a political privilege rather than a right.

An��economy��consists of the��economic system��of a country or��other��area; the��labor,��capital��and��land��resources; and the��manufacturing,��trade,distribution, and��consumption��of��goods��and services of that area.
Relating to an empire

Interventionism is a term for a policy of non-defensive (proactive) activity undertaken by a nation-state, or other geo-political jurisdiction of a lesser or greater nature, to manipulate an economy or society. The most common applications of the term are for economic interventionism (a state's intervention in its own economy), and foreign interventionism (a state's intervention in the affairs of another nation as part of its foreign policy).
An organization authorized by its greater society to��use force, usually including use of weapons, in defending its country by combating actual or��perceived threats.
Of or relating to recent times or the present

Refers to a post-traditional, post-medieval��historical period, one marked by the move from��feudalism��(or��agrarianism) toward capitalism,��industrialization,��secularization,��rationalization and the��nation-state.
Principles concerning the distinction between right and wrong or good and bad behavior.

May refer to a community of people who share a common language, culture, ethnicity, descent, and/or history. In this definition, a nation has no physical borders. However, it can also refer to people who share a common territory and government (for example the inhabitants of a sovereign state) irrespective of their ethnic make-up. In international relations, nation can refer to a country or sovereign state.
"the East." It is a traditional designation for anything that belongs to the��Eastern world��or the��Far East, in relation to Europe.
The ability or capacity to do something or act in a particular way.
Any physical��or��intangible��entity��that is��owned��by a��person��or jointly by a group of people or a legal entity like a corporation.
The��moral code��and��religious law��of��Islam.
The quality of having supreme, independent authority over a geographic area, such as a territory.
To��tax is to impose a financial charge or other levy upon a��taxpayer, usually an individual, by a��state such that failure to pay is punishable by law.
A flexible woven material consisting of a network of natural or artificial��fibres��often referred to as thread or��yarn.
The transfer of ownership of goods & services from one person or entity to another.
person from Yemen

the study of the physical features of the earth and its atmosphere, and of human activity as it affects and is affected by these, including the distribution of populations and resources and political and economic activities
unrest or rebellion, especially against a rightful ruler
the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca that all Muslims are expected to make at least once during their lifetime
the Islamic sacred book

an Indic language closely related to Hindi but written in the Persian script and having many loanwords from Persian and Arabic. It is the official language of Pakistan, and is also widely used in India and elsewhere
the Semitic language of the Arabs, spoken by some 150 million people throughout the Middle East and North Africa

a doctrine that holds decision making in a political field structured by the binary of friend and foe to be the main feature of politics
Hindu goddess associated with power
series of events that restored imperial rule to Japan in 1868
a rationale for colonization where colonization is held to spread 'civilization' among non-Western peoples
